title: 104_hr462
content:
SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled the "National Policies Toward Gambling Review Act of 1995." Congress found that in 1976, casino gambling was legal in only one state, Indian tribal gambling did not exist, and state lotteries were limited. The industry has since grown significantly, with casino gambling legal in over 20 states. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988 led to a rapid expansion of casino gambling in the United States, with Indian tribal casinos accounting for a significant portion of industry revenues. State lotteries are prevalent in 36 states, and gambling in some form exists in almost all states except for two. The impact of the gambling industry is a major public policy concern. The impact of the gambling industry raises concerns about addiction, crime, cross addictions, decreased worker productivity, and adverse effects on small businesses in communities where gambling is legalized. The gambling industry has led to a competitive atmosphere between states, Indian tribes, and bordering countries like Canada to attract gambling revenue. There are conflicts in regulatory structures between Federal oversight and State laws. There is a lack of national-level knowledge on the impact of gambling proliferation in the United States. Most economic impact studies on casino gambling are sponsored by the industry, with little funding for research on gambling addiction at the State or Federal level. Policymakers at all levels require data on the social and economic effects of gambling proliferation in the US. A commission called the "Commission on the Review of National Policies Toward Gambling" is established to review national policies on gambling. The commission's duties are outlined in the Act. The Commission on the Review of National Policies Toward Gambling will conduct a study on gambling activities in the US, their social and economic impact, and existing policies. The study will include an examination of the impact on small businesses and jobs. The Commission on the Review of National Policies Toward Gambling will study the impact of gambling addiction on businesses, jobs, and society. It will also review the effectiveness of current law enforcement practices and propose alternatives. Additionally, the study will analyze existing statutes at the federal, state, and local levels regarding the prohibition and taxation of gambling activities. The Commission will prepare proposals for codification, revision, or repeal of statutes to implement policy changes deemed necessary or desirable. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Four members each are appointed by the Senate President, Senate minority leader, House Speaker, and House minority leader, while seven are appointed by the President. Members must not be government officers or Congress members and should have relevant expertise. The President designates a Chairman from the Commission members. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by various officials. A quorum is eight members, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and members receive $100 per day for their duties. Federal judiciary members cannot receive additional compensation. Members also receive travel expenses. Each member of the Commission receives travel expenses, including per diem, as outlined in title 5, United States Code. SEC. 5. STAFF. The Chairman of the Commission has the power to appoint a Director and up to 15 staff members, without following certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The appointments must meet specific qualifications. The Chairman of the Commission appoints individuals with expertise in social sciences, law enforcement, and gambling-related areas. The Commission is granted powers under Section 6. The Commission, under Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain official data from government agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and use the United States mails for communication. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence within the United States as part of its investigative powers under this Act. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence, and if a person refuses to obey, the Commission can seek a court order for compliance. Subpoenas must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, and failure to comply may result in civil contempt charges. Service of process for court applications under paragraph (2) can be done in the judicial district where the person to be served resides or can be found. The Commission is considered a U.S. agency for immunity purposes under part V of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Commission may submit interim reports to the President and Congress as needed. A final report must be transmitted within 2 years of the first meeting, containing detailed findings and conclusions.

SEC. 8 TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 60 days after submitting the final report.
